question: When two aircraft are approaching head-on or approximately so and there is a danger of collision, each shall
answers: avoid the other by changing altitude.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: When two aircraft are converging headings at approximately the same altitude, the aircraft that has the other on its right shall give way except that, gliders shall give way to
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: 'Controlled Airspace' means an airspace of defined dimensions within which
answers: aircraft must proceed in accordance with a SCATANA clearance.
an Air Traffic Control (ATC) service is provided.
only aircraft equipped with functioning two-way radio may operate.
Control is provided for instrument flight rules (IFR) traffic only.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: Except for ultra-light aeroplanes, no person shall fly an aircraft in Canada unless
answers: there is in force with respect to aircraft a Certificate of Airworthiness or a Flight Permit.
its nationality and registration marks are affixed to the aircraft in a proper manner, and are clear and visible.
all of the above conditions are met.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: No person shall attempt to fly as a flight crew member of a glider if
answers: less than five take-offs and landings have been completed in the preceding six months.
within the preceding 12 hours alcohol has been consumed.
experiencing a physical disability likely to prohibit immediate licence renewal.
less than five supervised take-offs and landings have been completed in the preceding six months.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: Except when taking off from or landing at an airport or military aerodrome aircraft shall not be flown over the built-up areas of any city, town or other settlement or over an open-air assembly of persons except at an altitude that will permit in the event of an emergency, the landing of the aircraft without undue hazard to persons or to property on the surface; such altitude shall not in any case be less than . . . . . above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of two thousand feet from the aircraft. The correct entry to complete the blank space is
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: A steady green light directed at an aircraft in flight means
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: A glider is preparing for take-off from an aerodrome in the altimeter setting region. If the current altimeter setting is not available the altimeter shall be set to
answers: the mean sea level pressure of the aerodrome.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: The minimum flight visibility for VFR flight in a Control Area is
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: Every owner of an aircraft shall preserve the Aircraft Journey Log for
answers: one year after the date of the last entry in the log.
three years after the date of the last entry log.
as long as the aircraft has a valid Certificate of Airworthiness.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: An Air Traffic Control 'instruction'
answers: is in effect 'advice' provided by ATC and does not require acknowledgement by the pilot concerned.
is the same as an ATC 'clearance' when issued by a Flight Service Section.
requires compliance when received unless aircraft safety is jeopardized.
must be 'read back' in full to the controller and confirmed before becoming effective.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: No person shall walk, drive or park any vehicle on any part of an airport used for the movement of aircraft, except in accordance with permission given by the appropriate ATC unit or, in the absence of any such unit, by
answers: the local flying club or school manager.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: 'Day' in Canada is defined as that period of time between
answers: one hour before sunrise and one hour after sunset.
the end of morning civil twilight and the beginning of evening civil twilight.
the beggining of morning civil twilight and the end of evening civil twilight.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: Unless authorized by ATC, no person shall fly a glider within Class C airspace unless
answers: the pilot receives and acknowledges a VFR clearance to do so.
the ground visibility is at least 3 miles.
the pilot maintains a listening watch on an appropriate radio frequency.
all of the above conditions are met.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: The filing of a flight plan or itinerary is only required when a glider pilot plans to proceed
answers: to an altitude of more than 5,000 feet.
more than 25 NM from departure point.
questionSource: TP 877E, TC Sample Exam, 10th Edition, August 2006

question: An airport is
answers: an aerodrome with a control tower.
an aerodrome in respect of which certificate is in force.

question: The west end of a runway oriented east and west is numbered
The runway is lighted at night by two parallel lines of lights; taxiways by two parallel lines of lights.  The missing colours are
An aircraft is "cleared to the circuit" where a left=hand circuit is in effect.  Without further approval from ATC, a rght turn may be made to
answers: enter the circuit from the upwind side, crosswind or on the downwind leg.

question: The specified area associated with a mandatory frequency and within which a pilot is required to contact the ground station and report his intentions normally is
answers: 5 n.m. in radius and extends up to 3,000 ft AGL.
10 n.m. in radius and extends up to 3,000 ft AGL.
5 n.m. in radius and extends up to 5,000 ft AGL.
10 n.m. in radius and extends up to 5,000 ft AGL.

question: Pilots flying VFR and intending to land at an aerodrome where no madatory frequency, aerodrome traffic frequency or ground station exists, should broadcast their intentions on
A series of red flashes directed to an airplane in flight means
answers: give way to other aircraft and continue circling.
do not land for the time being.
you are in a prohibited area, alter course.

question: To transit VFR through any part of Class C airspace, pilots must
answers: have a special Class C endorsement to their licenses.
advise ATC of their intentions and obtain a clearance.
obtain prior permission in writing from the ATC unit.

question: To conduct a VFR flight in Class B airspace, a pilot must
answers: have a Class B license endorsement.
be flying an airplace equiped with a full IFR instrument panel.
advise ATC of his intentions and obtain a clearance.

question: The primary function of Class C Airspace to VFR flights is to
answers: provide headings to the pilot that will "home" the aircraft to the airport.
provide assistance to a pilot flying above an overcast cloud condition.
more efficiently integrate the flow of VFR and IFR flights within the classified airspace.
permit "Special VFR" flights to be conducted within the control zone.

question: An airspace classified as Class F and indicated on an aeronautical chart by the code CYA(S) denotes
answers: a danger aera with artillery activity.
a restricted area with surveillance activity.
an advisory area with soaring activity.

question: Which of the following extends upwards from the surface of the earth?
An area in which air traffic control extends upwards from a specified height above the surface is called
A flight plan must be filed for all VFR flights
When a VFR flight plan has been filed with the appropriate ATC unit, the pilot-in-command shall report his arrival within
A VFR flight plan must be closed by the pilot
answers: by advising ATC either directly or via a communications base of his arrival time.
except at airports served by a control tower in which case the tower will close the flight plan.
by parking his aircraft in close proximity to the tower.
by filing a return flight plan.

question: An Air Traffic Control "Instruction"
answers: is the same as an Air Traffic Control "Clearance".
must be complied with when received by the pilot to whom it is directed unless he considers it unsafe to do so.
must be"read back" in full to the controller and confirmed before becoming effective.
is in effect advice provided by ATC and does not require acceptance or formal acknowledgement by the pilot converned.

question: A pilot accepts a clearance and subsequently finds that all or part of the clearance cannot be compiled with.  He should
answers: comply as best he can under the circumstances to carry out the clearance and say nothing to ATC.
comply as best he can under the circumstances and advise ATC as soon as possible.
comply with only the part that suits him.

question: In Canada, flights conducted VFR Over The Top
answers: may not be conducted in Class C Airspace.
may be conducted if the weather at ground level is IFR.
may be conducted if the departure point and the destination are forecast to have VFR weather.

answers: Lima, Tango. Requesting Landing Information. Over.
Charlie, Golf, Uniform, Lima, tango. Over.

question: In subsequent transmissions, if initiated by ATC, the following may be ommited:
answers: the first two letters of the registration.
the first three letters of the registration.

question: The prefix of a call to the London flight sierve station should be
answers: London Flight Service Station, this is.

question: A radio-equipped aircraft has been cleared to land at a controlled airport. The pilot should acknowledge the clearance by
answers: transmitting the appropriate aircraft call sign.

"Daylight" in Canada, at any place where the sun rises and sets daily, is defined as that period of time
answers: commencing one hour before sunrise and ending one hour after sunset.
commencing one half hour before sunrise and ending one half hour after sunset.
when the centre of the sun's disc is not more than 12˚ below the horizon when viewed from the surface.

question: An islated thunderstorm is in close proximity to an aerodrome.  A pilot wishing to land should
answers: not be concerned about wind shear on final approach because the thunderstorm is off to the west and not over the approach path.
hold over a known point clear of the thunderstorm until it is well past the aerodrome.
land as quickly as possible to be on the ground before the thunderstorm reaches the aerodrome.
add one half the wind gust factor to the recommended landing speed.

question: One alcoholic drink taken at 5,000  feet as compared to the same drink taken at sea level.
answers: has no appreciable difference in effect.
increases the chance of coriolis effect.

question: Which of the following statements pertaining to the use of alcohol is true?
answers: Relatively small amounts of alcohol significantly decrease a pilot's tolerance of hypoxia.
Small amounts of alcohol will not affect a pilot's judgement.
The effects of alcohol are constant regardless of altitude.
Coffee accelerates the body's ability to recover from the effects of alcohol.

question: Select the statement that best describes the effects of fatigue.
answers: Financial or family problems do not influence fatigue.
Fatigue slows reaction time and contributes to errors.
a fatigued person recuperates more quickly as the altitude is gained.
A fatigued person must have food immediately before and during a flight.

question: After any underwater activity where compresed air is used for respiration and decompression stops are required during the ascent to the surface, it is recommended that within 24 hours following such activity a pilot should
answers: restrict flight to altitudes of less than 7,000 feet.
restrict rates of climb and descent to less than 300 feet per minute.
restrict flight to passenger status only.

question: Many common drugs such as cold tablets, cough mixtures, antihistamines and other over the counter remedies may serisouly impair the judgement and co-ordination needed while flying.  The safest rule is to
answers: read the manufacturer's warning to ensure that you are aware of possible reactions to such drugs.
allow at least 8 hours between taking any medicine or drug and flying.
allow at least 48 hours after commencing medication.
restrict flight to passenger status only.

question: A condition in which there is a lowering of the temperature of the body's core is called
